DOC.HEAD: U.S. Spokesman Said Fighting Has Subsided
DOC.UNK: EDITOR'S NOTE: The following report was filed by members of the Pentagon media pool that accompanied the U.S. invasion force into Panama.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military officials say they have concluded that most of the fighting between pro-Noriega forces and American troops has subsided and that little real threat remains. Col. Ronald Sconyers, director of public affairs for the U.S. Southern Command, said Wednesday evening that a lot of the sporadic gunfire still being heard around the country is from roving bands of Noriega loyalists, known as Dignity Battlations, who are ``just getting their last licks in.'' Early Wednesday morning, John Bushnell, the U.S. charge d'affaires in Panama, briefed the pool after President Bush spoke to the nation. He said it was the clear desire of the new government to take contol. Bushnell said he had dinner Monday night with three officials that U.S. authorities say were elected in May 7 balloting: President Guillermo Endara and Vice Presidents Ricardo Arias Calderon and Guillermo Ford. Noriega annulled the elections. After getting pledges of secrecy from the civilian leaders, Bushnell said he outlined the scope of the U.S. military plans. He said they wrote Bush a letter affirming their support for the U.S. assistance. Asked why the Panamanian civilian leaders had changed their minds about having U.S. rather than Panamanian forces oust Noriega, Bushnell said there had been no snap conversion. ``I don't think it was overnight,'' he said. ``It was a matter that the Panamanians weren't being very successful in doing it.'' After the failed coup on Oct. 3, he said, ``there was a feeling that, well, there weren't many more Panamanians left with guns that might do it, so it was becoming a hopeless situation.'' ``They never said it so many words, `we wish you would really send the 82nd Airborne to do it,' but they clearly indicated their frustration that if we didn't, the situation was just going to go on and get worse,'' Bushnell said. The new leaders' main concern, he said, was that if Noriega were shot, another Panamanian Defense Force colonel might take his place. Bushnell said he thinks ``it is certainly possible'' that Noriega might run for the hills to hide out or possibly seek refuge in Cuba or Nicaragua. But he said it was unlikely he would take to the hills to form a guerrilla movement inside Panama because he lacks sufficient popular support. Bushnell said calls were made to Panamanan Defense Force representatives by both the new government leaders and military officers. In some instances, he said, the military officers would speak to whomever answered the telephone at PDF headquarters and say in effect: ``This is suicide _ pack it in.'' At least two mortar rounds hit the embassy Wednesday, U.S. officials said. Bushnell said that although Noriega remained at large, officials had expectations at the outset of the operation that he could be seized. ``If he had been at one of the several places we took down, we would have gotten him. But he wasn't,'' Bushness said.
